A set is a collection of distinct objects considered as an entity.

The alternating group on $\{1, \ldots, n\}$, denoted as $\mathfrak{A}_{n}$, is the set of all even permutations in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$, i.e., those permutations for which $\operatorname{sgn} \pi = 1$. It forms a normal subgroup of index 2 in $\mathfrak{S}_{n}$.
Does the concept of a/an Set need to be defined for a definition of a/an Alternating Group to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: To determine if the concept of a set is necessary for the definition of an alternating group to make sense, we need to analyze the definition of the alternating group. The alternating group on a set of elements, specifically $\\[1, \\ldots, n\\]$, is defined as the set of all even permutations of the elements in $\\[1, \\ldots, n\\]$. A permutation itself is a rearrangement of the elements of a set. The definition of the alternating group explicitly uses the term 'set' to describe the collection of even permutations. Furthermore, the concept of a set is fundamental in understanding what permutations are, as permutations are rearrangements of the elements of a set. Therefore, without the concept of a set, the notion of permutations and, consequently, the definition of an alternating group, which relies on the concept of permutations, would not be properly defined or understood.
